#Text=XIX .
#Text=The Feast 's End
#Text=THE FEAST was a noble feast , as has already been said .
#Text=There was an elegant ingenuity displayed in the form of pies which delighted my heart .
#Text=Once acknowledge that an American pie is far to be preferred to its humble ancestor , the English tart , and it is joyful to be reassured at a Bowden reunion that invention has not yet failed .
#Text=Beside a delightful variety of material , the decorations went beyond all my former experience ; dates and names were wrought in lines of pastry and frosting on the tops .
#Text=There was even more elaborate reading matter on an excellent early-apple pie which we began to share and eat , precept upon precept .

#Text=Mrs. Todd helped me generously to the whole word BOWDEN , and consumed REUNION herself , save an undecipherable fragment ; but the most renowned essay in cookery on the tables was a model of the old Bowden house made of durable gingerbread , with all the windows and doors in the right places , and sprigs of genuine lilac set at the front .
#Text=It must have been baked in sections , in one of the last of the great brick ovens , and fastened together on the morning of the day .

#Text=There was a general sigh when this fell into ruin at the feast 's end , and it was shared by a great part of the assembly , not without seriousness , and as if it were a pledge and token of loyalty .
#Text=I met the maker of the gingerbread house , which had called up lively remembrances of a childish story .
#Text=She had the gleaming eye of an enthusiast and a look of high ideals .

#Text=“ I could just as well have made it all of frosted cake , ” she said , “ but ' twould n't have been the right shade ; the old house , as you observe , was never painted , and I concluded that plain gingerbread would represent it best .
#Text=It was n't all I expected it would be , ” she said sadly , as many an artist had said before her of his work .

#Text=There were speeches by the ministers ; and there proved to be a historian among the Bowdens , who gave some fine anecdotes of the family history ; and then appeared a poetess , whom Mrs. Todd regarded with wistful compassion and indulgence , and when the long faded garland of verses came to an appealing end , she turned to me with words of praise .
#Text=“ Sounded pretty , ” said the generous listener .
#Text=“ Yes , I thought she did very well .
#Text=We went to school together , an ' Mary Anna had a very hard time ; trouble was , her mother thought she 'd given birth to a genius , an ' Mary Anna 's come to believe it herself .
#Text=There , I do n't know what we should have done without her ; there ai n't nobody else that can write poetry between here and ' way up towards Rockland ; it adds a great deal at such a time .
#Text=When she speaks o ' those that are gone , she feels it all , and so does everybody else , but she harps too much .
#Text=I 'd laid half of that away for next time , if I was Mary Anna .
#Text=There comes mother to speak to her , an ' old Mr. Gilbreath 's sister ; now she 'll be heartened right up .
#Text=Mother 'll say just the right thing . ”
#Text=The leave-takings were as affecting as the meetings of these old friends had been .

#Text=There were enough young persons at the reunion , but it is the old who really value such opportunities ; as for the young , it is the habit of every day to meet their comrades , -- the time of separation has not come .

#Text=To see the joy with which these elder kinsfolk and acquaintances had looked in one another 's faces , and the lingering touch of their friendly hands ; to see these affectionate meetings and then the reluctant partings , gave one a new idea of the isolation in which it was possible to live in that after all thinly settled region .

#Text=They did not expect to see one another again very soon ; the steady , hard work on the farms , the difficulty of getting from place to place , especially in winter when boats were laid up , gave double value to any occasion which could bring a large number of families together .
#Text=Even funerals in this country of the pointed firs were not without their social advantages and satisfactions .
#Text=I heard the words “ next summer ” repeated many times , though summer was still ours and all the leaves were green .
#Text=The boats began to put out from shore , and the wagons to drive away .
#Text=Mrs. Blackett took me into the old house when we came back from the grove :
#Text=it was her father 's birthplace and early home , and she had spent much of her own childhood there with her grandmother .
#Text=She spoke of those days as if they had but lately passed ; in fact , I could imagine that the house looked almost exactly the same to her .

#Text=I could see the brown rafters of the unfinished roof as I looked up the steep staircase , though the best room was as handsome with its good wainscoting and touch of ornament on the cornice as any old room of its day in a town .
#Text=Some of the guests who came from a distance were still sitting in the best room when we went in to take leave of the master and mistress of the house .
#Text=We all said eagerly what a pleasant day it had been , and how swiftly the time had passed .
#Text=Perhaps it is the great national anniversaries which our country has lately kept , and the soldiers ' meetings that take place everywhere , which have made reunions of every sort the fashion .
#Text=This one , at least , had been very interesting .

#Text=I fancied that old feuds had been overlooked , and the old saying that blood is thicker than water had again proved itself true , though from the variety of names one argued a certain adulteration of the Bowden traits and belongings .
#Text=Clannishness is an instinct of the heart , -- it is more than a birthright , or a custom ; and lesser rights were forgotten in the claim to a common inheritance .
